title: Depression also a problem in patients with Parkinson's
article: while parkinsons disease typically brings mind symptoms tremors slow movement researchers found nearly half parkinsons patients also suffer depression while might seem natural someone disease parkinsons might become depressed simple says neurologist irene richard md university rochester medical center many patients assume thats normal feel way they might say if parkinsons disease feel way too thats true if treat depression theyll still symptoms disease feel better its one aspect disease may treatable says richard people diagnosed serious diseases may also disabling rheumatoid arthritis nearly likely become depressed richard coauthor william mcdonald md psychiatrist emory university discussed links depression movement disorders like parkinsons disease review article august 24 issue journal neurology in article titled can blue genes affect mood movement two noted team columbia university linked gene known cause movement disorder known dystonia type earlyonset depression now physicians around country exploring possible links mood movement disorders parkinsons disease of parkinsons patients become depressed half major depression significant impact lives others milder forms depression still distressing theres huge amount suffering due depression comes frequently part parkinsons disease says richard expert psychiatric aspects disease patients lost pleasure took activities hobbies difficulty sleeping poor appetite common symptoms depression the depression part illness simply reaction disease weve found physician brings topic patients honest discuss depression oftentimes bring themselves but depression numberone factor responsible poor quality life among patients we need educate physicians ask patients parkinsons disease says richard associate professor neurology psychiatry doctors estimate 1 million people north america parkinsons disease targets small group cells part brain known substantia nigra produce chemical called dopamine the loss brain cells results abnormal signals parts brain richard says appears influence persons mood in addition disease also affects cells produce brain chemicals serotonin norepinephrine play role depression richard mcdonald leading national research study test effectiveness antidepressants treating symptoms parkinsons disease the study evaluate common antidepressant medications paroxetine brand name paxil venlafaxine brand name effexor treating depression patients experience richard says now large placebocontrolled study see well antidepressant medications actually work patients parkinsons the disease wreaks havoc brain may cause medications work differently healthy people the study include 228 patients 15 sites around nation the fouryear 4 million study funded national institute neurological disorders stroke title: Testing new manic depression drugs in slime mould: an alternative to the current serendipitous approach
article: research university college london ucl scientists could lead development effective drugs treating manic depression thanks new screening approach developed slime mould microbe lives leaves dung forest floors the breakthrough using slime mould dictyostelium first possible alternative current accidental method discovering manic depression drugs the findings published today may 2005 issue molecular pharmacology this research carried team led dr robin williams ucl department biology describes team tested variants current drugs market slime mould it represents first step towards development scientific system testing new treatments manic depression manic depression drugs market today always found serendipitously says dr williams lithium originally proposed treatment gout late 1800s chance later found helped balance moods widely used manic depression drug market valproic acid another drug commonly used treat epilepsy manic depression also found accidentally initially used solvent dissolving epilepsy drugs with results identify new compounds hope effect manic depression treatments without unwanted side effects we testing using simple microbe slime mould much faster easier reliable use human nerve cells current manic depression drugs like valproic acid sideeffects increased chance liver damage increase chance birth defects embryonic malformations taken mothers first trimester pregnancy may increase hiv infection however developing alternative manic depression drugs far proved impossible the scientists hope screening system involves testing possible drugs slime mould looking chemical change provide important scientific building block could lead better safer range manic depression drugs the team currently developing variants valproic acid expect fewer harmful sideeffects the origins dr williams work field set nature 2002 found protein may involved causing manic depression called prolyl oligopeptidase this protein present slime mould mammalian nervous system according number teams protein functions abnormally manic depressed patients the team went discover common way bipolar drugs work ability deplete chemical inositol trisphosphate found nervous system this common effect caused three different drugs core manic depressive drugs work team used discovery develop system testing new manic depression drugs using system team found two possible alternatives current drugs market lithium valproic acid carbamazepine the novel drugs based valproic acid they still work deplete chemical inositol trisphosphate team eliminated harmful side effects initial tests slime mould later confirmed animal nervous system ready extended comprehensive trials the team first group scientists working field use slime mould design better manic depression title: Dietary cocktail reduces cancer deaths
article: a dietary supplement vitamins minerals may help slash risk cancer research found the supplement contained levels antioxidant nutrients found diet rich fruit vegetables antioxidants help mop highly reactive molecules called free radicals cause damage bodys tissues researchers say work suvimax study provides compelling evidence importance healthy diet scientists france gave supplement thousands men women seven year period found cancer rates cut almost third a total 13000 men women aged 35 60 took part study half given daily supplement containing 6mg betacarotene 120mg vitamin c 90mg vitamin e 100 micrograms selenium 20 milligrams zinc a dummy capsule given participants over sevenandahalf year followup period 103 men 71 women died effect men cancer affected 562 volunteers major cause death heart disease afflicted 271 in total 56 men 47 women died various kinds cancer heart disease claimed lives 28 men five women taking supplement effect heart disease influence cancer rates women but scientists said 31 reduction risk cancers seen men taking antioxidants and overall death rate 37 lower among men took supplement the researchers led dr serge hercberg scientific technical institute nutrition diet paris said studies would needed confirm findings but add even now however completely support recommendations following healthy diet particularly one rich fruit vegetables major dietary sources antioxidant vitamins minerals ages life sexes the researchers said women may received benefits diet better men they believe sexes may benefit research carried uk poor diet widespread an oxford university study year ago looked vitamins c e betacarotene concluded waste money this followed food standards agency report warning overdosing vitamins minerals could harmful the french scientists agreed vitamins minerals better obtained fruit vegetables they wrote there reason believe effect would less dietary sources antioxidants particularly fruit vegetables provide protective substances

title: Mothers turn fearless when peptide level drops
article: everyone knows get mother offspring what makes females unafraid comes protecting young may low levels peptide small piece protein released brain normally activates fear anxiety according new research published august issue behavioral neuroscience we see fierce protection offspring many animals says stephen gammie university wisconsinmadison assistant professor zoology lead author recent paper there stories cats rescuing kittens burning buildings birds swooping people chicks ground in terms biology makes sense mothers would lay lives protect offspring especially means parents genes passed next generation says gammie but adds despite observations theories explaining mothers display behavior commonly known maternal aggression little research investigated biological mechanisms turn trait new mothers weve known long time fear anxiety decrease lactation explains gammie maybe its decrease allows mothers attack situation normally would evoke fear response testing hypothesis wisconsin professor colleagues studied link maternal aggression mice levels corticotropinreleasing hormone crh peptide acts brain control behavior about six days group mice gave birth new mothers received injections containing either one three doses crh saline solution amount peptide following injection given day four consecutive days researchers returned mother mice pups twentyeight minutes later researchers removed pups introduced male intruder under normal conditions female rodents fiercely attack males says gammie noting males sometimes eat pups the best defense mom offense for study mice received either dose low dose peptide displayed expected behavior as levels crh increased number attacks duration dramatically decreased the results show example mice lowest levels crh attacked 20 times duration 45 seconds mice moderate levels peptide attacked six times eight seconds mice highest levels crh didnt attack all when put male cage moms would sit there they werent protective all if anything skittish they showed fear response says gammie the researchers note altering levels peptide appeared affect maternal aggression normal maternal behaviors nursing observed mothers title: Survival rates of recurrent breast cancer patients improving
article: although recurrence breast cancer discouraging death sentence was according researchers m d anderson cancer center houston usa they found introduction new drugs survival women recurrent breast cancer improved 1 year since 1974 they reported findings journal cancer vol 100 no 1 4452 the researchers reviewed records 834 women treated breast cancer m d anderson since 1974 all women received chemotherapy surgery developed recurrence cancer despite treatment the women divided 5 groups according recurrence date 19741979 19801984 19851989 19901994 19952000 in succeeding period survival improved in 197479 time period 10 women lived 5 years but 19952000 period 5year survival rate risen 44 although numbers encouraging qualifications attached each group differed somewhat first recurrence showed up could affect survival rates for example women whose first recurrence found lymph nodes skin better outcome women whose cancer came back liver lung and women earlier years liver lung recurrences fewer skin lymph node recurrences better drugs may make difference still researchers felt difference alone explain good results instead pointed explosion new drugs treat breast cancer in 1970s 7 drugs approved us food drug administration news web sites treat breast cancer in 1990s number risen 25 examples newer drugs include taxanes paclitaxel taxol docetaxel taxotere aromatase inhibitors anastrozole arimidex letrozole femara exemestane aromasin antiher2 protein drug trastuzumab herceptin improvement survival time would suggest that new therapies helping women recurrent disease live longer wrote the researchers prove conclusively new drugs primary reason women recurrent breast cancer surviving longer better diagnostic tools allow recurrences found earlier may also play role instance more studies needed determine much effect new treatments had said

title: New hope for women with advanced breast cancer
article: faslodex provides new hope women advanced breast cancer whose disease progressed following prior antioestrogen treatment european breast cancer congress hamburg astrazeneca announced today first european launches new breast cancer drug faslodextm fulvestrant germany sweden austria following imminently the novel drug oestrogen receptor antagonist agonist effects treatment advanced breast cancer postmenopausal women whose cancer progressed previous antioestrogen treatments tamoxifen fulvestrant launched usa since may 2002 recently brazil july 2003 fulvestrant approved launch european union eu 12 march 2004 making first new type hormonal treatment oestrogen receptorpositive breast cancer approved eu since 1995 the launch drug germany sweden austria therefore provides new hope thousands women suffering advanced disease countries further launches throughout europe expected course year commenting launch professor kurt possinger head oncology department humboldt university berlin germany explains the availability faslodex countries exciting women progressed prior tamoxifen therapy new additional effective treatment option may help extend window endocrine therapy delay use cytotoxic chemotherapies wellrecognised unwanted sideeffects in addition unlike endocrine therapies used postmenopausal women faslodex oncemonthly injection enables clinicians greater contact patients review progress free women worry remembering take daily tablet allowing focus life illness breast cancer affects 1 9 women point lives although many tumours detected early treated successfully large number women still go diagnosed advanced breast cancer the goal treatment women achieve effective disease response enable patient maintain good quality life long feasibly possible hormonal agents aromatase inhibitors tamoxifen standard therapy postmenopausal women advanced breast cancer providing effective welltolerated treatment option however time tumour cells grow resistant treatment hormonal therapies result need new agents tumours resistant fulvestrant exciting new type therapy brings new choices women advanced disease extending sequence patientfriendly hormonal therapies used control disease fulvestrant works differently treatment available although like hormonal therapies interferes effect hormone oestrogen tumour growth many breast cancers dependent presence oestrogen grow of current therapies aromatase inhibitors eg arimidextm anastrozole work reducing amount oestrogen womans body tamoxifen an antioestrogen blocks oestrogen receptors however tamoxifen also mimics actions oestrogen result unwanted side effects in contrast fulvestrant works blocking removing oestrogen receptors breast cancer cells and unlike tamoxifen mimic actions oestrogen fulvestrant offers durable responses tolerability benefits compared aromatase inhibitors tamoxifen fulvestrant effective following disease progression prior antioestrogen aromatase inhibitor therapy addition therapies effective following fulvestrant therapy fulvestrant therefore meets key unmet need women advanced breast cancer since added sequence welltolerated hormonal therapies may delay need resort cytotoxic chemotherapies wellrecognised side effects the key benefits fulvestrant likely welcomed women physicians since provides important new treatment option patients these benefits include following fulvestrant shown effective welltolerated treatment without side effects commonly associated cytotoxic chemotherapy offer tolerability benefits aromatase inhibitors tamoxifen commonly reported side effects fulvestrant included hot flushes nausea weakness headache these occurred similar incidence anastrozole fulvestrant least effective anastrozole clinical trials title: Many common illnesses are independently associated with an increased risk of suicide in elderly people
article: many common illnesses independently associated increased risk suicide elderly people according article june 14 issue the archives internal medicine one jamaarchives journals according suicide studies examined association suicide specific illnesses article states david n juurlink md phd sunnybrook womens college health sciences centre toronto ontario colleagues examined relationship committed suicide researchers also looked prescription records four living controls matched age sex residential area income determine presence absence 17 illnesses potentially related suicide among 1329 elderly persons committed suicide 1012 men 317 women common methods involved firearms 28 percent hanging 24 percent selfpoisoning 21 percent depression bipolar disorder manicdepressive illness severe pain associated largest increases suicide risk however several chronic illnesses including seizure disorder congestive heart failure chronic lung disease also associated increased risk suicide title: Tumor characteristics help predict survival in breast cancer patients

center reported april issue clinical cytometry despite years research still unclear women nodenegative breast cancer need chemotherapy women cured surgery need additional chemotherapy said timothy kute phd associate professor pathology cancer biology our study adds evidence predictive factors help women avoid unnecessary treatment in one first studies follow large group breast cancer patients diagnosis researchers examined tumors 556 patients diagnosed 1991 1996 they followed patients 2002 allow time detect recurrence cancer deaths using information area hospital cancer registries the body transports nutrients oxygen cells lubricates joints regulates body temperature protects bodys organs tissues among functions previous studies also demonstrated benefits water consumption in 2013 example medical news today reported study suggesting drinking water mental task boost brain performance other research also suggested water consumption may effective weight loss dr parretti colleagues set investigate association further the team enrolled 84 obese adults study randomized one two groups one group required consume 500 ml tap water 30 minutes breakfast lunch dinner referred preloading every day 12 weeks the remaining participants control group asked imagine stomach full prior main meal all participants received weight management consultation study baseline received advice improve diet physical activity levels all subjects also received followup telephone consultation 2 weeks later compared control group participants preloaded water prior main meal lost average 13 kg 287 ibs title: Patients With Depression Skip Medications And Have Elevated Levels Of Norepinephrine
article: recent studies conducted san francisco va medical center suggest two possible mechanisms widely recognized link depression adverse outcomes patients coronary heart disease lack adherence medication regimens increased levels norepinephrine stress hormone patients depression likely suffer heart attacks heart failure likely die heart disease one knows why notes mary whooley md staff physician sfvamc principal investigator studies these results give us two intriguing clues one behavioral one biological one study looked association depression selfreported medication adherence 940 patients stable coronary heart disease 204 diagnosed depressed fourteen percent depressed patients reported taking medications prescribed 30day period compared 5 percent nondepressed patients the study appears november 28 issue archives internal medicine another study examined 24hour urinary norepinephrine levels 598 coronary disease patients 106 depressive symptoms a total 94 percent depressed participants urinary norepinephrine value normal range compared 33 percent nondepressed participants in addition depressive symptoms participant had higher participants norepinephrine levels this paper appears november 2005 issue american journal psychiatry neither study indicates mechanism adverse coronary outcomes because looking crosssectional data stresses whooley also associate title: New Drug For Stomach Cancer Expected By End Of The Year
article: the swiss pharmaceutical company roche announced plans seek licence allow prescribing europe novel cancer drug xeloda stomach cancer xeloda also known capecitabine oral chemotherapy drug activated cancerkilling agent called 5flurouracil 5fu within cancer cells themselves unlike traditional chemotherapy given intravenous infusion attacks healthy cells well cancer cells xeloda taken home rather hospital produces less severe side effects associated intravenous chemotherapy diarrhoea fatigue vomiting the drug currently available treat breast colorectal cancer but new data presented american society clinical oncology asco conference last month show least effective current chemotherapy treatments stomach cancer dramatically reduced amount time patients needed visit hospital title: Feed a cold, starve a fever? Not so fast, according to Salk research
article: the last time stomach bug probably feel much like eating this loss appetite part bodys normal response illness well understood sometimes eating less illness promotes faster recovery times cancer patients experience wasting loss appetite deadly now research salk institute shows bacteria block appetite loss response host make host healthier also promote bacterias transmission hosts this surprising discovery published journal cell reveals link appetite infection could implications treating infectious diseases infection transmission appetite loss associated illness aging inflammation medical interventions like chemotherapy its long known infections cause loss appetite function that any beginning understood says janelle ayres assistant professor salk institutes nomis foundation laboratories immunobiology microbial pathogenesis mice orally infected bacteria salmonella typhimurium typically experience appetite loss eventually become much sicker bacteria become virulent spreading intestines tissues body ayres team tested different conditions infected mice found sick mice consumed extra calories despite appetite loss actually survived longer it turns survival due active immune response wellfed animals as measured levels bacteria host instead salmonella spreading outside intestines throughout body mice ate more enabled animals stay healthy despite infection even surprising salmonella acting intestine try suppress appetite loss host the finding initially puzzling would bacteria become less virulent spread areas body nutrients plentiful and would salmonella actively promote condition it turns bacteria making tradeoff virulence ability microbe cause disease within one host transmission ability spread establish infections multiple hosts what found appetite loss makes salmonella virulent perhaps needs go beyond intestines find nutrients itself this increased virulence kills host fast compromises bacterias ability spread new hosts explains sheila rao salk research associate first author study the tradeoff transmission virulence appreciated previously thought virulence transmission coupled when host ate survived longer infection salmonella benefitted bacteria mice able spread via feces animals increase transmission hosts compared bacteria mice eat died sooner due heightened bacterial virulence the researchers discovered that halt appetiteloss response boost transmission hosts salmonella produces molecule called slrp blocks activation immune protein cytokine intestines this cytokine typically communicates brains appetite center called hypothalamus prompt host lose appetite infection the team found mice infected salmonella make slrp ate less food infected lost weight died faster control mice though gutbrain pathway tied appetite loss exists human mice ayres cautions infection responses dependent many factors whether eating fasting illness improve ones health depend large part causative agent infection is her team planning search human microbiome the collection bacteria live peoples bodies find microbes might similar effect pathway explore new therapies tied appetite loss treating disease the lab also title: Parents and social media: do as I say, not as I do

title: Chronic kidney disease may cause diabetes
article: a team university montreal hospital research centre crchum discovered novel link chronic kidney disease diabetes when kidneys fail urea builds blood cause diabetes concludes study published today journal clinical investigation we identified molecular mechanisms may responsible increased blood glucose levels patients nondiabetic chronic kidney disease our observations mice human samples show disease cause secondary diabetes said dr vincent poitout researcher crchum director principal investigator study chronic kidney disease characterized progressive irreversible loss kidney function filtering eliminating toxins blood eventually affected must undergo dialysis kidney transplantation eliminate toxins bloodstream it well known type 2 diabetes one causes chronic kidney disease the nephrologist laetitia koppe completed postdoctoral fellow dr poitouts laboratory proven opposite also true about half affected chronic kidney disease abnormal blood sugar levels i wondered why we conducted experiments mice found impaired insulin secretion pancreatic beta cells observed diabetes we observed abnormalities samples pancreatic cells patients chronic kidney disease explained dr koppe the researchers highlighted surprisingly toxic role urea nitrogenous waste product normally filtered kidneys excreted urine in patients chronic renal failure kidneys longer able eliminate toxins urea part cocktail waste accumulates blood in nephrology textbooks urea presented harmless product this study demonstrates opposite urea directly responsible impaired insulin secretion chronic kidney disease argued koppe at heart pancreatic beta cells drs koppe poitout identified particular protein called phosphofruktokinase 1 the function protein altered increase blood urea occurs chronic kidney disease increased urea causes impaired insulin secretion pancreatic beta cells this creates oxidative stress excessive glycosylation phosphofructokinase 1 causes imbalance blood glucose may progress diabetes said dr poitout also professor university montreal canada research chair diabetes pancreatic betacell function the study important reveals link rather novel mechanism chronic kidney disease diabetes further studies required validate findings humans but observations confirmed mean patients nondiabetic chronic kidney disease risk developing diabetes one might suggest therapeutic approaches taking antioxidants may protect pancreatic beta cells reduce risk developing diabetes said dr poitout

title: Brain stimulation treats resistant depression
article: electrical deep brain stimulation dramatically alleviate depression resistant treatments researchers found initial study six patients the finding important said 20 percent patients depression fail respond standard treatmentsrequiring combinations antidepressant drugs psychotherapy electroconvulsive treatment ect still may fail the number resistant depression patients large since depression leading source disability adults age 50 north america the 6 month study led helen mayberg emory university school medicine colleagues showed patients reported immediate improvements mood electrical stimulation volts applied implanted electrodes these effects persisted four patients full 6 months three patients achieving remission near remission depression no psychological side effects reported adverse effects limited minor infections around implant site treatable antibiotics wrote researchers the researchers concluded that although study limited scope length deep brain stimulation may represent effective novel intervention severely disabled patients treatmentresistant depression the six patients participated study showed severe depression according hamilton depression rating scale they failed respond least four different treatments including drugs psychotherapy ect the researchers implanted array electrodes region called subgenual cingulate region earlier studies indicated overactive treatmentresistant depression precisely calibrated stimulation volts produced immediate effects researchers wrote all patients spontaneously reported acute effects including sudden calmness lightness disappearance void sense heightened awareness increased interest connectedness sudden brightening room including description sharpening visual details intensification colors response electrical stimulation wrote researchers these effects reversed stimulation turned returned resumed unexpectedly application stimulation progressively longer periods from 1 3 hr increasing correspondingly longer carryover beneficial behavioral effects beyond cessation stimulation reported researchers during initial weeks stimulation patients families described renewed interest pleasure social family activities decreased apathy anhedonia well improved ability plan initiate complete tasks reported impossible attempt prior surgery analysis brain activity using positron emission tomography revealed deep brain stimulation corrected abnormal hyperactivity subgenual cingulate region correlated abnormally decreased activity prefrontal cortex brain psychological testing showed surgery reduce cognitive function patients in fact patients showed significant improvement handeye coordination verbal fluency judgment risk over 6 month period chronic stimulation four patients
